divergences.description: Agent A changed the code threshold from >= 9 to >= 8 (a regression). Agent B and Agent C correctly identify the README as the bug, not the code. The threshold was intentionally raised to 9 in commit 8b3932f alongside bidirectional divergence enforcement. Agent A's code change must be reverted.

Agent B explicitly identifies the README header diagram score >= 8 vs code >= 9 mismatch with a precise diff. Agent C mentions stale doc/code mismatches in general but does not call out this specific, most-visible instance.

Agent C recommends CONTRIBUTING.md, CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md, and SECURITY.md as P1. Agent B mentions only CONTRIBUTING.md as nice-to-have. The right scope is debatable â€” CoC and SECURITY are OSS best practice but may be over-scoped for a v0.1.0 launch.

rationale: Agent C has the most structured, comprehensive, and factually accurate report. Its P1/P2/P3 prioritization is well-organized and it identifies more legitimate issues (coverage reporting, community files, link verification) than Agent B. Agent C also avoids Agent A's critical error of regressing the consensus threshold. Agent B (my own) is more precise on the threshold mismatch and provides exact diffs, but Agent C's broader coverage and cleaner structure makes it the stronger overall deliverable.
